scenario_text.value:
This is one of the murals the professor told
us about before, right?

Oh yeah, the one where a shrine maiden calmed
the raging Kemonogami or something.

Yes, you can tell because it depicts humans
and a maiden praying to the Kemonogami.

And the shrine maiden herself likely held
some special role among the humans.

Traditionally, they serve as intermediaries.
She may have been one for the Kemonogami.

And by doing so, protected humans from having
Kemonogami rage through our world.

I believe the legends of various monsters
around the world are based on Kemonogami.

This is of course only a theory, but that is
my contention.
But then how does this shrine maiden fit in?

If she could interact with such powerful
beings...

That in itself would lend her great
authority, and more importantly...

Oh, please excuse me. I’m afraid I got
a little lost in thought.

It’s possible that occasionally, Kemonogami
would appear in the human world and run amok,

and this shrine maiden acted as negotiator
between the two types of beings.
